conclusion: To compare average velocities, analyze vt graphs; average velocity is total displacement divided by total time.
The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the car.
For Car A, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve and the time axis.
For Car B, the area under the curve from t=0 to t=t1 is the region bounded by the curve and the time axis.
The displacement of Car A from t=0 to t=t1 is the area under the curve for Car A.
The displacement of Car B from t=0 to t=t1 is the area under the curve for Car B.
The area under the curve for Car A is larger than for Car B, indicating greater displacement for Car A.
Average velocity is total displacement divided by total time.
For Car A: average velocity is displacement of Car A divided by t1.
For Car B: average velocity is displacement of Car B divided by t1.
Since Car A's displacement is greater and time is the same, Car A's average velocity is greater than Car B's.
